docs.title: gooseBit
docs.text: A simplistic, opinionated remote update server implementing hawkBit™'s DDI API.

docs.title: Docker Compose Demo
docs.text:
The Docker Compose demo docker/demo/docker-compose.yml may serve as inspiration for a containerized (cloud) deployment. It uses PostgreSQL as the database and NGINX as a reverse proxy.

[!WARNING] Do not use the demo (as-is) in production!

Make sure you have Docker (and Docker Compose) installed. Then run:

docker compose -f docker/demo/docker-compose.yml up

Visit gooseBit at: https://localhost

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
gooseBit can be configured through a configuration file (/etc/goosebit.yaml) or by setting environment variables. For the available options and their defaults, see goosebit.yaml. The environment variable corresponding to e.g. the poll_time YAML setting would be GOOSEBIT_POLL_TIME. Environment variables for nested settings are constructed using __ as the separator:

GOOSEBIT_DEVICE_AUTH__ENABLE=true

Alternatively, a JSON string can be assigned:

GOOSEBIT_DEVICE_AUTH='{"enable": true}'

docs.title: Database
docs.text:
By default, SQLite is used as the database. For more sophisticated setups, PostgreSQL is supported. To use PostgreSQL, set db_uri or the GOSSEBIT_DB_URI environment variable to something like:

postgres://user:password@host:5432/db_name

docs.title: Artifact Storage
docs.text: The software packages managed by gooseBit are either stored on the local filesystem (artifacts_dir setting) or an S3-compatible object storage.

docs.title: Assumptions
docs.text:
• Devices use SWUpdate or RAUC + RAUC hawkBit Updater for managing software updates.
  • Devices send certain attributes (sw_version, hw_boardname, hw_revision).
  • Semantic versions are used.

docs.title: Device Registry
docs.text:
When a device connects to gooseBit for the first time, it is automatically added to the device registry. The server will then request the device's configuration data, including:

  • hw_boardname and hw_revision: Used to match compatible software.
  • sw_version: Indicates the currently installed software version.

The registry tracks each device's status, including the last online timestamp, installed software version, update state, and more.

docs.title: Software Repository
docs.text: Software packages (*.swu/*.raucb files) can be hosted directly on the gooseBit server or on an external server. gooseBit parses the software metadata to determine compatibility with specific hardware models and revisions.

docs.title: Device Update Modes
docs.text: Devices can be configured with different update modes. The default mode is Rollout.

docs.title: 1. Manual Update to Specified Software
docs.text: Assign specific software to a device manually. Once installed, no further updates will be triggered.

docs.title: 2. Automatic Update to Latest Software
docs.text: Automatically updates the device to the latest compatible software, based on the reported hw_boardname and hw_revision. Note: versions are interpreted as SemVer versions.

docs.title: 3. Software Rollout
docs.text: Rollouts target all devices with a specified "feed" value, ensuring that the assigned software is installed on all matching devices. Rollouts also track success and error rates, with future plans for automatic aborts. If multiple rollouts exist for the same feed, the most recent rollout takes precedence.

docs.title: Pause Updates
docs.text: Devices can be pinned to their current software version, preventing any updates from being applied.

docs.title: Real-time Update Logs
docs.text: While updates are in progress, gooseBit captures real-time logs, which are accessible through the device repository.

docs.title: Initial Setup
docs.text:
Install Poetry as described here.

Then, to install gooseBit's dependencies, run:

poetry install

Initialize the database:

poetry run aerich upgrade

Launch gooseBit:

poetry run python -m goosebit

The service is now available at: http://localhost:60053

docs.title: Database
docs.text:
Initialize or migrate database:

poetry run aerich upgrade

After a model change create the migration:

poetry run aerich migrate

To seed some sample data (attention: drops all current data) use:

poetry run generate-sample-data

docs.title: Code formatting and linting
docs.text:
Code is formatted using different tools

  • black and isort for *.py
  • biomejs for *.js, *.json
  • prettier for *.html, *.md, *.yml, *.yaml

Code is linted using different tools as well

  • flake8 for *.py
  • biomejs for *.js

Best to have pre-commit install git hooks that run all those tools before a commit:

poetry run pre-commit install

To manually apply the hooks to all files use:

poetry run pre-commit run --all-files

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Tests are implemented using pytest. You can run all the tests with:

poetry run pytest

To run only the unit tests:

poetry run pytest tests/unit

To run only the end-to-end tests:

poetry run pytest tests/e2e

docs.title: Running the Containers
docs.text: docker compose -f docker/docker-compose-dev.yml up --build

docs.title: Applying the Migrations
docs.text: docker exec goosebit-dev python -m aerich upgrade

docs.title: Using the Interactive Debugger
docs.text:
You might need rlwrap to fix readline support.

Place breakpoint() before the code you want to debug. The server will reload automatically. Then, connect to remote PDB (when the breakpoint has been hit):

rlwrap telnet localhost 4444

To exit the debugger, press Ctrl + ] and then q.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
The structure of gooseBit is as follows:

  • api: Files for the API.
  • ui: Files for the UI.
  • bff: Backend for frontend API.
  • static: Static files.
  • templates: Jinja2 formatted templates.
  • nav: Navbar handler.
  • updater: DDI API handler and device update manager.
  • updates: SWUpdate/RAUC file parsing.
  • auth: Authentication functions and permission handling.
  • models: Database models.
  • db: Database config and initialization.
  • schema: Pydantic models used for API type hinting.
  • settings: Settings loader and handler.
  • storage: Storage for software artifacts.
  • telemetry: Telemetry data handlers.
  • routes: Routes for a giving endpoint, including the router.

docs.title: gooseBit Plugin for Forwarded HTTP Header Support
docs.text: Enables the use of standard Forwarded HTTP headers (RFC 7239). This has been introduced because uvicorn (in conjunction with gunicorn) does not support the feature (yet): uvicorn#2237

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
When using a Docker image, the plugin can be installed as follows:

FROM upstreamdata/goosebit

USER root

RUN pip install --no-cache-dir goosebit-forwarded-header

USER goosebit

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Enable the plugin in goosebit.yaml (or set the corresponding environment variable):

plugins:
  - goosebit_forwarded_header

docs.title: gooseBit Simple Stats Plugin
docs.text:
A simple example plugin for testing and understanding gooseBit's plugin system.

This plugin sets up a page which shows software count and/or device count.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
When using a Docker image, the plugin can be installed as follows:

FROM upstreamdata/goosebit

USER root

RUN pip install --no-cache-dir goosebit-simple-stats

USER goosebit

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Enable the plugin in goosebit.yaml (or set the corresponding environment variable):

plugins:
  - goosebit_simple_stats

Configure which data to show:

simple_stats_show:
  - device_count
  - software_count
